info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 28 at 11:12PM EDT until August 29 at 3:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM EDT TUESDAY FOR CENTRAL IREDELL COUNTY... At 1112 PM EDT, The slow-moving storms responsible for the torrential rainfall across central Iredell County have moved well east of the area. Storm-total rainfall of 2-5 inches fell within 1-2 hours across the warned area, with isolated totals of 5-6 inches per reports from Emergency Management. Rainfall of this intensity historically produces areas of significant flash flooding. A few flood-prone locations, including along Davie Ave, the Fourth Creek Greenway, the Statesville Soccer Complex, and Old Mocksville Rd, have been impacted by flash flooding, but no additional significant impacts have been reported. However, given the amount of rain that has fallen over a large area in a very short period of time, it is likely other impacts have occurred but are difficult to see in the dark. Therefore, please exercise extreme caution on area roadways as flooded or washed out roadways can be very difficult to see at night. This remains a dangerous, life-threatening situation. Please stay away from all streams and adjacent low-lying areas for the next several hours. Light to isolated moderate rainfall is ongoing across the warned area and light rain is expected to persist for at least the next hour but this is not expected to contribute to the ongoing flash-flood threat. Nevertheless, it will take at least a few more hours for the floodwaves to work through area streams, including Fourth Creek; therefore, even though the heavy rain threat has ended, streams will continue to rise and remain above bankfull for some time. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar and Rain Gauges IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Deeper flooding of common, flood-prone areas is likely, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Campgrounds adjacent to streams may see significant flash flooding, capable of lifting campers. Rapid stream flows over roadways is likely with culvert washouts possible. A few low-water crossings may become impassible. A few structures adjacent to streams may be inundated. Some locations that may continue to experience flash flooding include... Statesville, Scotts and Cool Springs. The heaviest rainfall and greatest flash flood threat is along and near Fourth Creek from Statesville and points east, including near Statesville Country Club, US 64, E Broad St, Bell Farm Rd, I-40, Old Mocksville Rd, and Beechwood Farm Rd. This area received 3-5 inches of rainfall in less than two hours. Pockets of moderate rain may develop over the next couple of hours, capable of producing a quick half inch to one inch of rain in a short period of time, and while this is not likely to cause new flooding, it may prolong ongoing high flow conditions along small streams. Later into the overnight hours, additional heavy rain cannot be ruled out. Stay weather aware. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
